author: .vbuterin
content: Remind me: does the current EIP 1559 support zero-gasprice (or generally, gasprice < basefee) transactions or not? If not, why not?

author: .vbuterin
content: One big reason I see to be in favor is the work on democratizing MEV extraction by Phil Daian and others, which could potentially give us account abstraction by the backdoor; but that would require zero-gasprice transactions to be possible to actually work

author: .vbuterin
content: Though I guess there are alternatives. One option would be creating an entire standard for metatransactions that are just serialized descriptions of calls and making the MEV optimizers themselves look for these metatransactions and create a single "regular" gas-paying tx that packages them. This would also have the advantage of avoiding the 21000 per-transaction gas cost

author: .vbuterin
content: Regardless, I do think that more conversation on how to make these generalized MEV optimizers work well with high-level protocol goals could be worthwhile

author: sky.cactus
content: Does block reward go out before or after the transactions in a block?

author: sky.cactus
content: That is unfortunate.  Before would let you use the block reward on paying base fees, so the bundle could be signed by the miner's counbase.

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm, why would it matter, if you can just make a [block reward] sized budget and then subtract fees paid from that at the end

author: .vbuterin
content: though I suppose that's not a complete solution anyway since we're hoping for eventually burned fees > issuance, and if *all* fees end up being through some L2 mechanism then that inherently wouldn't work because it would directly imply that the protocol is pushing the coinbase balance down, which would be insecure

author: sky.cactus
content: I have been operating on the assumption that all clients deduct gas fees as they go and don't allow it to ever be zero, not that balances just need to be positive by the end of the block.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless perhaps you are saying that we could change that in a HF?

author: .vbuterin
content: right, clients definitely don't ever allow balances to be "temporarily negative"

author: .vbuterin
content: So theoretically, you could have an HF where you just allow gasprice < basefee, and then just impose a constraint that "final coinbase balance >= initial coinbase balance" for the block to be valid

author: .vbuterin
content: though I suppose this could run into issues like "what if someone is receiving $xx from some third party, and then an evil mining pool sets them to be the coinbase and fills the block just to drain their money, and includes that transaction which they would get anyway to make it 'look like' they're not being cheated"

author: .vbuterin
content: So okay, I'm convinced that solving those issues is hard enough that it risks delaying eip 1559 too much to try to solve them

author: .vbuterin
content: And it's probably better to just convince the MEV optimizers to include a metatransaction protocol

author: sky.cactus
content: The original specification was like that, but it was removed because it adds complexity and no one could come up with a compelling argument to keep it at the time.
